Title: Limit of $L^p$ norm
Content: Could someone help me prove that given a finite measure space $(X, \mathcal{M}, \sigma)$ and a measurable function $f:X\to\mathbb{R}$ in $L^\infty$ and some $L^q$ , $\displaystyle\lim_{p\to\infty}\|f\|_p=\|f\|_\infty$ ? I don't know where to start.
AcceptedAnswer:
Fix $\delta>0$ and let $S_\delta:=\{x,|f(x)|\geqslant \lVert f\rVert_\infty-\delta\}$ for $\delta<\lVert f\rVert_\infty$. We have 
$$\lVert f\rVert_p\geqslant \left(\int_{S_\delta}(\lVert f\rVert_\infty-\delta)^pd\mu\right)^{1/p}=(\lVert f\rVert_\infty-\delta)\mu(S_\delta)^{1/p},$$
since $\mu(S_\delta)$ is finite and positive. 
 This gives 
$$\liminf_{p\to +\infty}\lVert f\rVert_p\geqslant\lVert f\rVert_\infty.$$
As $|f(x)|\leqslant\lVert f\rVert_\infty$ for almost every $x$, we have for $p>q$, $$
\lVert f\rVert_p\leqslant\left(\int_X|f(x)|^{p-q}|f(x)|^qd\mu\right)^{1/p}\leqslant \lVert f\rVert_\infty^{\frac{p-q}p}\lVert f\rVert_q^{q/p},$$
giving the reverse inequality.

Let (X, M, μ) be a finite measure space with μ(X) < ∞. The function f: X → ℝ is measurable with f ∈ L^∞(X) and f ∈ L^q(X) for some q. For p ≥ q, define the L^p norm as ||f||_p = (∫_X |f|^p dμ)^{1/p}. The L^∞ norm is defined as ||f||_∞ = ess sup_{x∈X} |f(x)| = inf{M ≥ 0: μ({x ∈ X: |f(x)| > M}) = 0}.

**Step 2: Define the set S_δ**
For any δ > 0, define S_δ = {x ∈ X: |f(x)| > ||f||_∞ - δ}. By definition of the essential supremum, μ(S_δ) > 0 for all δ > 0 (otherwise ||f||_∞ - δ would be an essential bound, contradicting the minimality of ||f||_∞).

**Step 3: Upper bound for ||f||_p**
For any p ≥ q, we have:
||f||_p = (∫_X |f|^p dμ)^{1/p} ≤ (∫_X ||f||_∞^p dμ)^{1/p} = ||f||_∞ (∫_X dμ)^{1/p} = ||f||_∞ μ(X)^{1/p}
This inequality holds because |f(x)| ≤ ||f||_∞ for almost every x ∈ X by definition of the essential supremum.

**Step 4: Lower bound for ||f||_p**
For any p ≥ q and any δ > 0, we have:
||f||_p = (∫_X |f|^p dμ)^{1/p} ≥ (∫_{S_δ} |f|^p dμ)^{1/p} ≥ (∫_{S_δ} (||f||_∞ - δ)^p dμ)^{1/p} = (||f||_∞ - δ) μ(S_δ)^{1/p}
The first inequality follows because we integrate over a subset S_δ ⊆ X. The second inequality holds because for x ∈ S_δ, we have |f(x)| > ||f||_∞ - δ by definition of S_δ.

Taking the limit superior as p → ∞ in the upper bound inequality:
limsup_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≤ limsup_{p→∞} (||f||_∞ μ(X)^{1/p}) = ||f||_∞ lim_{p→∞} μ(X)^{1/p}
Since μ(X) is finite and positive, we have lim_{p→∞} μ(X)^{1/p} = 1 (because for any finite positive constant C, lim_{p→∞} C^{1/p} = 1). Therefore:
limsup_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≤ ||f||_∞

From the lower bound inequality, for any fixed δ > 0:
liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≥ liminf_{p→∞} ((||f||_∞ - δ) μ(S_δ)^{1/p}) = (||f||_∞ - δ) lim_{p→∞} μ(S_δ)^{1/p}

liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≥ ||f||_∞ - δ for every δ > 0

Since the inequality liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≥ ||f||_∞ - δ holds for every δ > 0, we can take the supremum over all δ > 0 to obtain:
liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≥ sup_{δ>0} (||f||_∞ - δ) = ||f||_∞
This is because for any ε > 0, we can choose δ = ε/2 to get liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≥ ||f||_∞ - ε/2 > ||f||_∞ - ε, and since ε is arbitrary, the inequality must hold.

We have established:
limsup_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≤ ||f||_∞ ≤ liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p
By properties of limit superior and limit inferior, we always have liminf_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≤ limsup_{p→∞} ||f||_p. Combining these inequalities gives:

Therefore, the limit exists and:
lim_{p→∞} ||f||_p = ||f||_∞

**Step 2: Upper bound for ||f||_p**

||f||_p = (∫_X |f|^p dμ)¹/ᵖ ≤ (∫_X ||f||_∞^p dμ)¹/ᵖ = ||f||_∞ (∫_X dμ)¹/ᵖ = ||f||_∞ μ(X)¹/ᵖ

If ||f||_∞ = 0, then f(x) = 0 almost everywhere, which implies ||f||_p = 0 for all p. The equality lim_{p→∞} ||f||_p = ||f||_∞ holds trivially as 0 = 0.

limsup_{p→∞} ||f||_p ≤ ||f||_∞
